text: @joshuacfoy EXACTLY. My father is probably the strongest person I know, and he cries at insurance add because he’s not afraid to show his emotions

Masculinity has nothing to do with beards and good looks and how you respond to criticism. It is all about your choice to stand up for what you believe in. This guy here was told to do get this singer off stage and instead comforted her in a moment which must’ve been absolutely heart-wrenching. Masculinity is about being there for other people, no matter superficial things like race and gender, and supporting them in their time of need. Another often forgotten part of it, but equally important, is letting others help you when you need support.
@jessicakroche more disrespectful to ignore and condone the global abuse of children by catholic priests. But sure. Ripping up a picture is far more damaging.
I have loved Kris Kristofferson my whole life. He is easy on the eyes for sure, but more importantly he is a good person.

@micayla_micayla_micayla I think “toxic masculinity” is the wrong term. Instead, it’s almost more like a bastardization of masculinity, and how some (many?) in society have warped the meaning of masculinity to include horrible acts and disrespect toward women.
@dkremaro wow. You are a big man for admitting that. Respect. 👍🏼

@dkremaro 😒

Has nothing to do with “toxic masculinity” that’s not even a real thing btw lmao 😂 she disrespected a very powerful religious figure of course you’re going to have back lash no matter how bad the person was

@micayla_micayla_micayla Toxic Masculinity doesn’t pertain to *acts*, it talks about the shallow, surface ideals of “manliness” which puts pressure on men to act in a certain way (clothing, locker room talk, muscles, sports) to be considered to be a man, without allowing the deep inner work of what being masculine actually means to come through (moral fortitude, inner strength, wisdom, compassion, caregiving, etc). It’s when the farce of “manhood” overwhelms the good qualities of men and the bad acts you listed come out— symptoms of men not feeling adequate because of the pressure they put in each other. It’s a lot like how women experience toxic femininity when they berate each other as sluts or fat— we put the most pressure on each other to be superficially feminine instead of allowing the true feminine nature to surface. I’d love to see men concerned about that, but it’s rare to see a man that isn’t happy to hear a woman call another women a slut (thanks to toxic masculinity that teaches caring about women isn’t manly). If that makes more sense to you.
@jessicakroche Yes, enablers of child abuse/sex trafficking do deserve far more respect than we give them, those poor, misunderstood pedophiles. 🎻

It was beautiful until the last slide. There is absolutely no science behind the “toxic masculinity” narrative. Many men are raised by single mothers, are around female teachers most of their childhood and become sexual assault perpetrators. Statistics show that  men who are raised with a masculine presence actually respect women. Masculinity is necessary for male child development. Being a narcissist is toxic. Being a rapist is toxic. Being a deranged sadistic person is toxic. None of these are directly related to masculinity.

@annaleesalvatore I don't like organized religion at all either. But your comment wasn't sound. The argument based on flawed logic. She singled out a singular man who was guilty at that time of covering up crimes against children. And I generally can't stand whataboutism. It's reduced all debates to the level of 3rd grade. The President of the United States even does it🤦🏻‍♂️. Whataboutism serves to make sure nothing ever changes gets done or is addressed.

@dkremaro she converted to Islam. I am waiting to see if she will be consistent with caring about abuse victims by calling out Muslims equivalents of the pope. I find it weird that she cares about victims but will also be part of an ideology that has similar people. You aren’t shredding anything or anybody. Pipe down. Writing all that must have made your thumbs hurt 😂

@annaleesalvatore so you are saying the comparison of Mohamed who lived thousands of years ago to the elected Popes of the Catholic Church of today is correct? Are you really that daft? No you can't be more wrong. The correct correlation would be Jesus to Mohammad and let's say a Imam of a Mosque to the Pope of the Catholic Church. So tell me how Mohammad is relevant to the Pope? Then explain what Mohammad has to do with a live flesh and blood elected leader currently alive and making decisions for a church and sect of Christianity. Now you could say why does someone slam Christianity and not Islam. That's two religious philosophies. And even then what flawed logic you would be using. Because A) saying what you said is called whataboutism. If that's the rule we live by then no one can ever speak up about anything. Because injustice exists around the world in many forms. So if someone needs to include ALL injustices when they speak out about one because of you whataboutism folks... then no one can ever meet that threshold and no one then should ever speak out against anything. Whataboutism is the logic only intellectually dishonest or inept people use. And reason B) why you your logic is bull shit is this woman wasn't speaking out against Christianity. But see you don't know how to have a real debate or be intellectually honest about it. She was singling out a ELECTED OFFICIAL from a church. For PERSONALLY knowing and being responsible for covering up sex abuse against minors by clergy. I can go on and shred you some more in this conversation...

@rafaelkg24 blah blah blah.... Stop deflecting from  the real issues dude. Im not only  talking about bad men. Its much more than that. Its toxic when women think they should get the door open for them by men and they should pay for dates and a number of societal pressures put on men.  Unfortunately for you that is also a part of toxic masculinity.  Its not men vs women issue . You have a simplistic view on this issue and maybe just maybe if your first instinct when you read about toxic masculinity is to ignore everything the phrase stands for talk about "bad women" then you'd understand that nobody said men are bad and women are good and always the victim. Its what you infer because you are in a way deflecting.  Just FYI (because you are too "simple" upstairs) - there are just as many bad women as there are bad men. You happy? 💁

That argument is pathetic and you are frankly doing a disservice to the entire male gender. I never claimed this is how men act. Sure do men roughhouse more and physically fight yeah but they get over their indifferences much faster than any woman out there .
